In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Pacific Financial Technical Assistance Centre (PFTAC) was established in 1993 by 
the United Nations Development Programme and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to 
assist economic growth and development in Pacific island countries.1 Since then, PFTAC has 
provided  support  in  four  key  areas:  (i)  public  financial  management,  (ii)  tax  policy  and 
administration, (iii) banking regulation and supervision, and (iv) economic and financial statistics. 
 
2.  This technical assistance (TA) is consistent with the Pacific Approach 2010–20142 of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB), which identifies continued support for good governance and 
regional cooperation and integration activities. ADB’s Pacific Regional Operations Business 
Plan provides for continued ADB support for PFTAC, with a $1 million contribution over 3 
years.3 PFTAC support complements other technical assistance (TA) projects undertaken in the 
region by ADB in the areas of public financial management,4 economic management,5 and 
external audit.6 ADB continues to work closely with PFTAC to avoid duplication and overlap in 
activities, while providing comprehensive support to Pacific island countries in these areas. 
 
3.  Since 1994 ADB has provided a total of $5.4 million to PFTAC under nine consecutive 
regional TA projects complementing other development partners’ support to PFTAC. The most 
recent support provided was for 2008–2011.7 The continued funding by ADB has been based 
on PFTAC’s successful track record and ability to deliver timely, high-quality, cost-effective 
technical advice to Pacific DMCs, along with a number of successful capacity development 
programs. In addition, PFTAC increases efficiency through pooling of resources from a number 
of development partners, and by providing a one-stop-shop for technical specialized economic 
and financial advisory services in the Pacific. 
 
4.  During the most recent meeting of the Tripartite Review Committee (TRC)8 in September 
2010, PFTAC presented its strategy for the fourth financing cycle covering 2011–2016.9 The 
strategy  was  developed  by  PFTAC  after  consultations  with  the  representatives  of  various 
institutions  of  Pacific  developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  and  development  partners, 
including ADB. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  Despite  continued  reform  efforts  and  some  successful  implementation,  weaknesses 
remain in financial and economic management in Pacific DMCs due to institutional capacity 
constraints  and  lack  of  adequate  technical  skills.  These  weaknesses  have  become  more 
apparent as a result of the global financial and economic crisis, which adversely affected Pacific 
island economies through falling tourist numbers, a reduction in exports, and reduced foreign 
remittances. Macroeconomic policy failures, weak revenue structures, limited private sector

2   
development, and weak public financial management have all been identified as significant 
contributing factors. Capacity remains a compelling problem for the region due to the small size 
of public administrations, reliance on a small number of qualified individuals, and the ease of 
out-migration. 
 
6.  A number of independent reviews have concluded that PFTAC has been successful due 
to its positioning within the region, responsiveness, and ability to fill a niche that cannot be 
readily filled by other TA projects.10 The most recent review noted that PFTAC delivers high 
quality, effective and efficient services to Pacific DMCs and its performance was rated as good. 
The two most frequently cited factors contributing to PFTAC’s success were its location in the 
region and the high quality of its expertise. Other reasons included PFTAC’s responsiveness to 
government priorities, consistent engagement over a period of years, personal relationships with 
Pacific DMCs, and knowledge of its member countries. Due to this, the work of PFTAC has 
been well received by Pacific DMCs, particularly in diagnosing the challenges and supporting 
the development of reform strategies. PFTAC continues to deliver training, workshops and 
attachments on a regional and subregional level. The training is also well received by Pacific 
DMCs who have rated highly the quality of resource persons, topics covered and presentations. 
 
7.  In  general,  PFTAC  activities  have  had  political  and  management  support  of  the 
beneficiary agencies, and therefore have yielded positive changes in policies and procedures 
that have become institutionalized. One area where PFTAC has been particularly successful in 
ensuring sustainable capacity is the development and ongoing support for regional professional 
associations such as the Pacific Islands Financial Managers Association and the Pacific Islands 
Tax Administrators Association. 
 
8.  Since 2008, PFTAC has sought additional resources to expand its activities and has 
increased  the  number  of  resident  advisors  from  four  to  five  with  the  addition  of  one 
macroeconomic  advisor.  PFTAC’s  draft  program  document  for  the  fourth  financing  cycle 
proposes further increases in resident advisors as PFTAC seeks to broaden its activities in 
statistics and public financial management, with an additional advisor to be appointed in each of 
these  areas.  In  statistics,  and  economic  statistics  in  particular,  the  Pacific  remains 
underdeveloped—only four countries (Fiji, Kiribati, Tonga, and Vanuatu) have subscribed to the 
IMF’s General Data Dissemination System and none currently are close to the Special Data 
Dissemination Standard.12 In public financial management, the additional advisor will focus on 
supporting the Public Expenditure and Financial Accountability (PEFA) assessment process, 
which has been given increased emphasis through the public financial management road map 
approved by Pacific Forum Leaders and Finance Ministers in 2010.13 
 
9.  PFTAC will, in the new funding cycle, continue to be a source of high quality assistance 
that is provided in a flexible and responsive manner that meets the important needs of its 
members. There continues to be a strong need and an equally strong demand for the activities 
and support provided by PFTAC. The focus of PFTAC’s work will continue to be on building 
capacity, in collaboration with other TA providers, in order to improve the skills and institutional 
capacities of members and strengthen the implementation of reform programs. 
 
                                                
10 The most recent review was IMF. 2009. Independent Evaluation of the Pacific Financial Technical Assistance 
Centre. Washington, DC. 
12 The General Data Dissemination System and the Special Data Dissemination Standard are IMF standards that 
provide guidance on the dissemination to the public of economic and financial data. 
13 Pacific Islands Forum Secretariat. 2010. A Public Financial Management Roadmap for Forum Island Countries.

III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
10.  The TA will continue ADB’s support of PFTAC through 2011–2014. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The impact will be for Pacific island countries to achieve economic and financial policy 
objectives to contribute to sustainable economic growth. The outcome will be strengthened 
institutional and human resource capacity of Pacific island countries’ finance ministries and 
central banks to improve economic and financial management in Pacific island countries. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  The TA will deliver outputs in line with PFTAC’s key areas of advisory services and 
capacity building activities over the TA period (2011–2014). The outputs reflect all activities 
proposed by PFTAC (consistent with prior financing cycles, ADB and development partner 
funds, as with earlier TAs, are pooled and managed by the IMF). 
 
13.  The outputs (and associated activities) are: 
 
(i)  Public  financial  management  strengthened.  Activities  in  public  financial 
management will be focused around the regional public financial management 
roadmap and will be focused in two areas (i) supporting the PEFA assessment 
process and development of realistic reform priorities; and (ii) continued hands-
on technical support and training in specific reform areas, which are expected to 
include  improved  legal  frameworks,  budgeting  cycles,  cash  management, 
commitment expenditure controls and accounting processes and procedures. 
 
(ii)  Revenue  systems  developed  to  be  more  broadly-based  and  efficient. 
Adopting the model tax office developed through the regional tax administrators 
association, PFTAC will assess and monitor the national tax administrations of 
Pacific island countries against the regional benchmark. Priorities are expected 
to be value-added tax implementation, compliance strategies, and information 
technology strategies. PFTAC will continue to support the Oceania Customs 
Organization, focusing mainly on enhancing information technology and updating 
legislation.  Given  fiscal  adjustment  pressures  facing  many  Pacific  island 
countries, tax policy assistance is also expected to be a high priority in the early 
part of the funding cycle. 
 
(iii)  Identified financial system risk factors addressed and minimized. PFTAC 
will  continue  to  assist  in  the  development  of  appropriate  regulations  and 
statistical returns and the regular production of financial soundness indicators. 
The focus of support is expected to move towards building capacity for on-site 
examination, in particular analysis of asset quality and the implications for the 
adequacy  of  bank  capital  and  earning  performance.  Assistance  in  non-bank 
supervision  will  continue  to  be  provided.  PFTAC  expects  the  Australian 
Prudential Regulation Authority to take a lead in this area, but will also provide 
assistance, particularly with respect to insurance and provident funds.

4   
 
(iv)  More  timely  and  reliable  economic  statistics. PFTAC’s support to Pacific 
island countries’ statistics will take place in the context of the regional statistical 
benchmarking study and its implementation plan. National accounts statistics will 
be the main focus of the first resident advisor, with the second advisor initially 
focusing on external statistics. The emphasis of the second advisor will change 
during the cycle, depending on regional priorities. The advisor will coordinate 
closely with the Secretariat of the Pacific Community, which will have a large 
program of support focused on producing source data vital for improvement of 
macroeconomic statistics. 
 
(v)  Improved  macroeconomic  analysis.  The  advisor  will  focus  on  improving 
macroeconomic  forecasting,  strengthening  the  framework  for  inter-agency 
coordination,  building  in-country  capacity  for  debt  sustainability  analysis, 
increasing the use of financial programming techniques (particularly in countries 
facing a substantial short-term adjustment need), and developing more effective 
monetary and exchange rate frameworks. The advisor’s work will be closely 
coordinated  with  IMF  surveillance,  in  particular  through  IMF’s  new  regional 
representative, and other development partners such as ADB that are involved in 
regional monitoring and analysis. 
 
14.  These outputs are described in detail in the strategy document for the fourth financing 
cycle (footnote 8). 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000 equivalent and will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources) and administered by the 
IMF. The total cost of operating PFTAC14 is to be jointly funded with the European Union,15 the 
IMF, and the governments of Australia, the Republic of Korea, and New Zealand. The IMF has 
committed $2.7 million while the remaining development partners are in the process of finalizing 
their funding commitments. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The  IMF  is  the  executing  agency  and  PFTAC  is  the  implementing  agency.  The 
arrangements for the funding of PFTAC will be consistent with the requirements established 
under all previous TA projects. ADB’s funds will be pooled with those from other development 
partners and managed by the IMF. 
 
17.  On approval of the TA, the IMF will provide ADB with a letter of understanding that 
governs ADB’s contribution towards PFTAC activities. The IMF is responsible for PFTAC’s 
managerial, technical, and administrative arrangements along with the relevance and quality of 
PFTAC assistance. The IMF (i) assigns the coordinator of the center, (ii) selects the resident 
advisors from their professional staff, (iii) hires short-term experts using IMF procedures and 
                                                
14 PFTAC’s strategy for the fourth financing cycle contains two options (i) a proposed expansion of PFTAC activities 
with a corresponding increase in costs, for an estimated total of $30 million over 5 years; and (ii) maintaining the 
current scope of operations over the 5 years for an estimated total of $22 million. The outcome of the current fourth 
funding cycle will influence the option taken. Governments of recipient countries have been asked to make a 
contribution to the fourth financing cycle. 
15 The European Union is a new contributor to PFTAC under the fourth funding cycle.

5 
draws on experts from its approved rosters, (iv) provides supervision and support services, (v) 
provides  administrative  support,  and  (vi)  manages  the  cost-sharing  contributions  of  the 
development  partners.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  made  in  three  equal  annual 
installments ($333,333 per annum) to PFTAC over the TA period (2011–2014). 
 
18.  PFTAC's resident advisors and short-term experts will be recruited and supervised by 
the IMF in accordance with its standard practices. IMF selection procedures are consistent with 
ADB Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Because 
ADB's funds will be pooled with those from other development partners and will be managed by 
the IMF through the application of the IMF’s policies, it requires ADB Board approval.  
 
19.  TA activities will be implemented over 36 months, starting in July 2011. The expected 
financial completion date of the TA is August 2014. 
 
20.  Monitoring of the TA will draw on the findings of assessments by the IMF. Biannual 
reports will be prepared by the PFTAC coordinator and distributed to all PFTAC contributing 
development partners detailing progress against an agreed results framework. Strategic and 
operational issues will be monitored at the TRC meeting (held every 18 months). PFTAC also 
maintains its own website providing regular updates against activity plans and country strategies. 
Lessons and good practices will be disseminated throughout the duration of the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION AND DECISION 
21.  The President recommends that the Board approve, by a vote of directors representing 
not less than two-thirds of the total voting power of the members, the use of IMF recruitment 
guidelines for the procurement of consultants for the Pacific Financial Technical Assistance 
Centre 2011-2014. 
 
22.  If the Board approves the proposal in paragraph 21, the President, acting under the 
authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  will  approve  the  provision  of  technical  assistance  not 
exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis for the Pacific Financial Technical 
Assistance Centre 2011-2014.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
 
1.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  funds  are  pooled  with  those  from  other 
development partners and managed by the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The IMF is 
responsible  for  the  Pacific  Financial  Technical  Assistance  Centre’s  (PFTAC)  managerial, 
technical, and administrative arrangements along with the relevance and quality of PFTAC 
assistance. The IMF (i) assigns the coordinator for the center (full time staff member), (ii) selects 
the  resident  advisors  from  their  professional  staff,  (iii)  hires  short-term  experts  using  IMF 
procedures and draws on experts from its approved rosters, (iv) provides supervision and 
support  services,  (v)  provides  administrative  support,  and  (vi)  manages  the  cost-sharing 
contributions of the development partners. The IMF is therefore responsible for the terms of 
reference for the program advisors and the short-term experts engaged. The following are a 
synopsis of the activities for each program advisor’s area. 
 
2.  All advisors are expected to provide direct technical assistance (TA) on a range of 
issues for their specialist areas to the Pacific island countries covered by PFTAC. They will also 
supervise the TA work of short-term experts financed by PFTAC for those areas. 
 
B.  Scope of Consulting Services 
 
1.  Program Area 1: Public Financial Management (2 advisors) 
3.  The public financial management (PFM) advisor(s) work program should cover all PFM 
areas:  legal  and  regulatory  framework;  budget  preparation  (including  budget  classification, 
medium-term  budgetary  frameworks,  performance-oriented  budgeting);  budget  execution 
(including  expenditure  control,  treasury  operations,  cash  management,  accounting,  fiscal 
reporting, and financial management information system); internal control; and internal audit. It 
will also include the realization or supervision of assessments under the Public Expenditure and 
Financial Accountability PFM Performance Measurement Framework. The advisor(s) should 
have regular interaction and cooperation with development partners and Pacific developing 
member countries (DMCs) on regional and country-specific PFM reform activities. 
 
4.  The  PFM  advisor(s)  will  facilitate  the  implementation  of  the  regional  PFM  reform 
roadmap and work closely with Pacific DMCs and development partners to develop country-
specific  PFM  reform  strategies.  The  advisor(s)  will  actively  promote  formal  capacity 
development activities through the continuation and deepening of the Pacific Islands’ Financial 
Managers’ Association as a regional practitioner's forum, the development of training materials, 
and the conduct of PFM training programs relevant to the region as a whole. In addition to 
existing capacity building initiatives it is expected that PFTAC will work with the Australian 
Ministry of Finance and Deregulation for capacity development and implementation and with 
ADB on the development of a regional Accounting Centre of Excellence. 
 
2.  Program Area 2: Revenue Policy and Administration 
5.  The revenue policy and administration advisor work program should cover all revenue 
areas and policy advice including frameworks, legislation, information technology strategies and 
tariff setting. On tax administration the focus will be indirect, corporate, personal and property 
taxes; providing assistance on improving the effectiveness of tax and customs administration 
including  via  risk-based  compliance;  strengthened  collection,  audit,  and  taxpayer  services;

Appendix 3  11 
establishing special collection arrangements for larger business taxpayers and modernizing 
customs procedures; advising on implementing new taxes; and introducing measures to bring 
medium and small taxpayers into the tax net. 
 
6.  The revenue advisor will coordinate with Pacific DMCs and development partners and 
other agencies to ensure that advice is coordinated and implementation can be well targeted. 
PFTAC will actively promote formal capacity development activities through the continuation 
and deepening of the Pacific Island Tax Administrators Association with a focus on developing 
(i)  a  model  tax  framework  with  legislation;  (ii)  regional  training  programs;  (iii)  a  regional 
information technology strategy; and (iv) a regional communication strategy, which includes the 
development of a Pacific Island Tax Administrators Association website. 
 
3.  Program Area 3: Financial Sector Supervision and Regulation  
7.  The financial sector supervision and regulation advisor work program should cover all 
areas of banking regulation and supervision including governance, framework, legislation, and 
regulation development. The advisor will continue to develop capacity  regarding prudential 
supervision  activities,  including  both  banks  and  non-bank  financial  institutions.  Supervision 
activities should include on-site supervision and off-site surveillance, and the movement of 
supervisory  agencies  towards  risk-based  assessments  of  banks  and  their  overall  financial 
soundness. At the institute level advice will be provided on strengthening internal operating 
policies and procedures, and enhancing data capture and analysis capacity. Short-term experts 
will be used mainly to support non-bank supervision (e.g., of insurance and provident funds). 
 
8.  The  advisor  will  coordinate  with  Pacific  DMCs,  development  partners,  and  other 
agencies to ensure that advice is coordinated and implementation can be well targeted. PFTAC 
will  actively  promote  formal  capacity  development  activities  through  the  continuation  and 
deepening the Association of Financial Supervisors of Pacific Countries and will arrange an 
annual meeting for members to network and exchange experiences. PFTAC will continue to 
hold regional training through the Association of Financial Supervisors of Pacific Countries and 
it  is  expected  that  a  subregional  approach  will  also  be  adopted  through  supervision  staff 
completing  on-site  examinations  in  other  jurisdictions,  thus  focusing  on  practical  issues  of 
common interest to subregional groups. 
 
4.  Program Area 4: Economic and Financial Statistics (2 advisors) 
9.  The  economic  and financial  statistics  advisor(s)  provide  advice  at  the  regional  and 
national level to support the coverage, quality and timeliness of government financial statistics. 
The General Data Dissemination System (GDDS) and the Data Quality Assurance Framework 
(DQAF) of the IMF will continue to be used as frameworks for statistical development. Advice 
will  be  provided  on  organizational,  strategic  and  legislative  issues  and  will  strengthen  the 
development of statistics to enhance macroeconomic monitoring. There will be a strong focus 
on national accounts; broader, more frequent measures for GDP; and regular rebasing of 
constant price estimates. A second advisor may be required to focus on external statistics to 
support other macroeconomic areas. This will focus on the development and broadening of 
indicators such as GDP estimates, GNDI and GDI. 
 
10.  The advisor(s) will coordinate with Pacific DMCs and development partners and other 
agencies to ensure that advice is coordinated and implementation can be well targeted. The 
advisor(s) will actively promote formal capacity development activities through the continuation 
and deepening the Pacific Island National Accounts Compilers and Local Experts Association.

12  Appendix 3 
The advisor(s) will hold regional training workshops to promote regional best practice  and 
arrange attachments to other statistical agencies in New Zealand and Australia. 
 
5.  Program Area 5: Macroeconomic and Frameworks Advisor 
11.  The macroeconomics and frameworks advisor is a new program area for PFTAC, which 
is currently working closely with the ADB’s Pacific Economic Management TA. It is expected 
that close coordination between ADB and PFTAC in this field will continue for some time. The 
advisor is expected to focus on building capacity to (i) better utilize national accounts and 
balance of payments statistics, (ii) make improved economic growth forecasts and informed 
decisions on monetary and exchange rate policies, (iii) analyze debt sustainability, and (iv) 
improve the transparency of economic and financial information by making it more accessible to 
the public in PICs. 
 
12.  The advisor will coordinate with Pacific DMCs and development partners and other 
agencies to ensure that advice is coordinated and implementation can be well targeted. PFTAC 
will actively promote formal capacity development activities, which initially will focus on training 
courses for financial programming, and forecasting techniques at the regional and subregional 
levels organized in conjunction with the IMF institute. The advisor will work with the Bank of 
England’s Centre for Central Banking Studies to organize courses on key central banking issues, 
as well as contributing to regional analyses for central bank governors, finance ministers and 
other interested parties.
